results.title: Facing it: my friend's an alcoholic
results.creator_credit: George McQuilkin, Churchill Films and William Haugse
results.brief_description: Terry, 17, has a drinking and drug problem and his friend, A.J., is being drawn into it. A.J. at first covers for Terry, then tries to intervene. Finally he realises, with the assistance of Terry’s girlfriend, that they need outside help.

results.title: Facing facts
results.creator_credit: Peter Dimond, Supreme Sound Studios and Barrie Smith
results.brief_description: The death of a close friend affects Glen Turner so much that he reflects on how his own death would affect his family’s financial security. In a discussion with an Officer of a Trustee company he learns of the steps he can take to alleviate any hardship in the event of unexpected tragedy.

results.title: Faces of the enemy
results.creator_credit: Quest, Catticus, Bill Jersey and Jeffrey Friedman
results.brief_description: Why do we see those with whom we are in conflict as monstrous and inhuman enemies? Recent events such as the fundamentalist Muslim death threats to Salman Rushdie or the upsurge of racist violence in Australia, raise questions about what drives nations and individuals to make monsters out of those they perceive as enemies. Faces of the Enemy is a fascinating yet disturbing film which presents a vivid picture of the ways in which societies create an image of the enemy, then become obsessed with this image to the point of being prepared to kill without guilt. In a chilling series of images we see the enemy depicted as demons, barbarians, madmen or vile animals to be exterminated without regret. Presented by Sam Keen
results.creator_credit_for_label: Quest, Catticus, Bill Jersey and Jeffrey Friedman

results.title: Faces of the city
results.creator_credit: David Bairstow, Malcolm Smith and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”.
Illustrates the five general zones of activity distinguishable in the major cities of Australia, showing the characteristic land use and activities of each.

results.title: Faces of India: Raju, a guide from Rishikesh
results.creator_credit: Face Film Productions and Yavar Abbas
results.brief_description: Gives an intimate insight into the lives of the ordinary people in Rishikesh in the Himalayan foothills. The film follows a nine-year-old boy through a day’s work taking visitors around the town. We hear Raju giving facts and figures and details of everything he sees. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Faces of culture
results.creator_credit: Ira R. Abrams, Harry Ratner and Coast Community College District
results.brief_description: The long human journey on this planet has taken diverse peoples over countless trails in all cardinal directions. Subtitled “Studies of cultural anthropology”, this series looks at some of these directions, and at fundamental patterns common to all cultures. Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: Faces in the sun
results.creator_credit: Richard Mason, Methodist Overseas Mission and Cecil Holmes
results.brief_description: The story of four aboriginals grappling with assimilation pressures and facing a changing future. Through the experience of a bark painter, a teaching assistant, a carpenter, and a tribal headman, we see the type of life each one lives, and the conflict of the old and the new which sets up tensions within each one, and in Aboriginal society. (Award: Gold Award, General Category, Australian Film Awards, 1965).

results.title: Faces in the Street
results.creator_credit: K Porteous, Australian Broadcasting Commission and Douglas White

results.title: Faces in a crowd
results.creator_credit: David Powell, Abacus Documentaries and Roger Dunton
results.brief_description: Looks at the city of London and shows how the Port and the city are complementary, mutually supporting a vast trading complex. This relationship is largely revealed in this film in terms of people - working people - in the markets, for which the city is justly famous.
